chunk_summary: This section discusses diagnostic and treatment pitfalls in typhoid and enteric fever, emphasizing proper antibiotic use, diagnostic accuracy, and the role of vaccination and WASH measures in prevention.
learning_objectives: Understand the diagnostic challenges and limitations of serological tests like Widal in endemic areas.
Learn appropriate antibiotic stewardship practices, including de-escalation based on susceptibility data.
Recognize the indications for corticosteroid use in severe enteric fever cases.
Appreciate the role of vaccination and WASH measures in reducing typhoid incidence.
key_facts: Fever may persist for up to 7 days on effective therapy, especially with cephalosporins.
Widal test results are unreliable in endemic areas and should not replace culture-based diagnosis.
Empiric fluoroquinolones are generally avoided in children due to resistance and safety concerns.
High-dose dexamethasone is reserved for enteric fever with shock or encephalopathy.
Vaccination reduces typhoid but not paratyphoid; WASH measures remain essential for prevention.
reference_quote: Fever may take up to a week to resolve on effective therapy, especially with cephalosporins; judge response by toxicity, intake, and hemodynamics, and change antibiotics early only when the child is worsening or clearly not improving by day 5–7. (Source: National Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases, India)
